repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Second Agricultural Sector
            Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Irrespective of the valuable
            contribution that the project made in providing guidance to
            the Government concerning reforms in the agricultural
            sector, at the time of project completion the project is
            considered to have an unsatisfactory outcome. World Bank and
            Borrower performances are generally satisfactory. The key
            lessons learned from this project's implementation are:
            In designing projects which are expected to induce
            institutional reform, a phased, realistic implementation
            time frame which can adjust to changes in government will
            and commitment should be given. Technical assistance can be
            effective in providing analysis and guidance to government.
            However, the actual implementation of genuine reform depends
            on clear commitment to action from Government and other
            stakeholders. Conditionalities have not worked, and
            strengthening analytical capacity has not yielded the
            intended impact in an environment in which all aspects of
            the reform process are politicized. The complexity of
            agro-industrial reform, particularly in the sugar industry,
            was underestimated at appraisal. There were technical,
            financial, industrial policy, and political factors which
            have caused the delay in reforms to this sub-sector. The
            lesson is that planning the reform of such industries
            requires stronger government commitment and the
            participation of key stakeholders.

18152825.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Kenya - Second Agricultural Sector
            Management Project (ASMP II)

abstracts.cdata!:
The main project goals are to: (a)
            develop key agricultural sub-sectors by fostering greater
            private sector involvement; (b) reform the cooperative
            sector to make cooperatives more efficient and responsive to
            member needs; (c) increase the overall efficiency of
            Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) and Ministry of Livestock
            Development (MOLD) by rationalizing their role, structure
            and strategic functions; and (d) ensure the sustainable use
            of Kenya's physical resources by strengthening the
            capability in Government to factor in the impact on the
            environment of agricultural programs and policy initiatives.
            Project components include the following: (a) developing the
            cotton subsector; (b) restructuring of the sugar subsector;
            (c) developing the oilseeds subsector; (d) restructuring of
            the cooperative subsector; (e) developing capacity in
            Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) and Ministry of Livestock
            Development (MOLD); (f) strengthening the Department of
            Resource Surveys and Remote Sensing (DRSRS); and (g)
            developing the institutional capacity to prepare and
            implement a National Environment Action Plan (NEAP).
